tutorial.title: Selecting Data
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to select specific parts of data or all data stored in a table.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent:
Many apps allow you to interact with stored data, such as usernames, passwords, or friends lists.

This kind of data lives in a database.

lessons.title: SQL
lessons.interactiveContent:
We'll now learn SQL, a language that helps us work with databases.

SQL is a programming language we use to select, modify, and insert data in databases.

lessons.title: Tables
lessons.interactiveContent:
Most databases are collections of tables storing different pieces of data.

Tables are like spreadsheets, storing information about a specific kind of data, such as this table storing users' names and usernames.

lessons.title: Tables - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
In many databases, each entry has a unique ID called a primary key to help identify records easily.

See how every entry now has an ID that identifies the person in the list of friends.

lessons.title: Rows
lessons.interactiveContent: Each row of a table represents a new item. The first row contains data about a user item's ID 1, name John Doe, and username @johndoe.

lessons.title: Columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Each column of a table represents a specific attribute of the data, such as id, name, or username.

These columns define the type of information stored for each item in the table.

lessons.title: Question: SQL
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is SQL?

A programming language we use to select, modify, and insert data in databasesA programming language we use to code website interfaces

A programming language we use to select, modify, and insert data in databases.

lessons.title: Question: Rows
lessons.interactiveContent:
If every row stores an item, how many user items does this table store?

Three user items, because it has three rowsWe can't know how many user items it stores

Three user items, because it has three rows.

lessons.title: Question: Columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
If rows stand for items, what are columns?

Properties of each user item, like a name or emailEach column stands for a different user item

Properties of each user item, like a name or email.

lessons.title: Lesson #10
lessons.interactiveContent:
Let's write our first line of SQL together!

We'll use the following table of users to work with.

lessons.title: Question: FROM - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We code SELECT to retrieve data from a database.

Make sure to pick SELECT.

lessons.title: Question: FROM - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
We code SELECT, followed by the name of the column we want to pick. Let's pick the column called name to select the names' of our users.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by name.

lessons.title: SELECT statement - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, we need to define the table we want to query by coding FROM followed by the table's name.

Make sure to pick FROM, followed by users.

lessons.title: SELECT statement
lessons.interactiveContent:
Finally, though it might seem minor, it's important to remember that we end an SQL statement with a semicolon.

Make sure to pick ;.

lessons.title: SELECT statement - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
And there you have it: your first SQL statement that selects all names from our users table.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by name and then FROM, users, ;.

lessons.title: Query
lessons.interactiveContent:
When requesting data with SQL statements like SELECT, we say that we're making a query.

Make sure to pick SELECT.

lessons.title: Upper case
lessons.interactiveContent:
To tell apart SQL keywords from column and table names, we write them in upper case. Tap on the code and type FROM.

Make sure to type FROM.

lessons.title: Question: FROM
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the FROM users statement do?

It says which table we want to select the name column fromIt renames a column

It says which table we want to select the name column from.

lessons.title: Example: Query
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a query that selects all titles from the movies table with SELECT title followed by FROM movies;.

Make sure to pick SELECT title, followed by FROM movies;.

lessons.title: Semicolon
lessons.interactiveContent:
While not necessary, it's considered good practice to finish your SQL queries with a semicolon ;.

Make sure to pick ;.

lessons.title: FROM
lessons.interactiveContent:
Query the species from the animals table.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by species and then FROM, animals, ;.

lessons.title: Example: Semicolon
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a semicolon ; at the end of this query that selects all rating values in the movies table.

Make sure to type ;.

lessons.title: Question: SELECT
lessons.interactiveContent:
What keyword do we use to select data from a given table?

SELECTDELETE

Make sure to pick SELECT.

lessons.title: Select multiple
lessons.interactiveContent:
With SQL, we can also select multiple columns in one query.

Select values from both the name and email columns by coding SELECT name, email.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by name,, and finally email.

lessons.title: Commas
lessons.interactiveContent:
When selecting multiple columns, we use commas , to separate column names, like here with name, email.

Make sure to pick ,.

lessons.title: Select all columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
To select all columns of a table like stock, we'd have to code all of their names, like description, s, m, l here.

Make sure to pick ,, followed by ,, and finally ,.

lessons.title: Select *
lessons.interactiveContent:
To make things easier, we can select all columns of a table using the select all symbol * instead.

Make sure to pick *.

lessons.title: Example: Select *
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code SELECT * to select all columns of this books table.

Make sure to type SELECT *.

lessons.title: Question: Select multiple
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query do?

It selects values from both the name and email columnsIt only selects values from the email column

It selects values from both the name and email columns.

lessons.title: Example: commas
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a comma , to separate the columns in this query.

Make sure to type ,.

lessons.title: Question: Select multiple - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query do?

It selects values from all columnsIt selects values from both the name and email columns

It selects values from all columns.

lessons.title: Question: Select multiple - Copy - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select all values using the select all symbol.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by *.

lessons.title: Selecting with duplicates
lessons.interactiveContent:
When selecting a column that has duplicate values like country here, we get all the values, including duplicates.

Make sure to type country.

lessons.title: Question: Select distinct
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can use DISTINCT to only select unique values, removing any duplicates from the results of our query.

Make sure to pick DISTINCT.

lessons.title: Distinct
lessons.interactiveContent:
When we use the keyword DISTINCT, we eliminate duplicates from the columns we select, like the duplicate France and England values.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by DISTINCT, and finally country.

lessons.title: Example: Distinct
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use DISTINCT to find out what music genres this user listens to.

Make sure to type DISTINCT.

lessons.title: Question: Select distinct - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the DISTINCT keyword in this query do?

It selects values from the country column, excluding duplicatesIt selects values from the email column

It selects values from the country column, excluding duplicates.

lessons.title: Example: Distinct - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select all values from genre (without using DISTINCT) to check if there are duplicates.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by genre.
